bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William Crawford Gorgas, February 7, 1918

div1.p: [Carter] believes it would be a mistake to place the U.S. Public Health Service under War Department control permanently, but agrees that temporary control would help the war effort.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William Crawford Gorgas, February 7, 1918
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Baltimore, Md.,
February 7, 1918.
Dear Gorgas:
div1.p:
You are quoted--Washington Post--as advising the Senate
Committee that it would be an advantage to have the P. H. S. as-
signed to you during the war for extra cantonment work etc.

I have thought of this matter no little since you spoke
of it in New Orleans and have spoken of it to many officers of
my Service and State Health Officers. Practically all hold that
as a permanent change it--the militarization of our national
health service--would be a backward step in sanitation, but
everyone, and myself, are not only willing, but desireous of
this--or any other change--which increases the efficiency of
the United States in the war.

As to whether it would increase efficiency, I would say
that it looks reasonable that activities under one head are apt
to be better coordinated than if under more than one--no matter
how earnest is the cooperation of the different chiefs. I am
sure, however, that you have had, and will have, this cooperation
from my Service to the limit.

Dr. Welsh's judgment on this should be good. I at least,
and I think all who know him, would accept it as final, as I know
of no one who has so clear and broad a view of sanitary problems.
